title: Earthquake
overview: An earthquake is the shaking of the surface of the Earth resulting from a sudden release of energy in the Earth's lithosphere that creates seismic waves.
tips: Drop, Cover, and Hold On - this is the most important action during an earthquake
Stay away from windows, mirrors, and heavy objects that could fall
After shaking stops, evacuate carefully using stairs, never elevators
If you're outdoors, move to an open area away from buildings, trees, and power lines
If you're in a vehicle, pull over to a safe location and stay inside
Have an emergency kit ready with water, food, first aid supplies, and medications
response: Check for injuries and hazards like gas leaks, electric lines, and structural damage
Use text messages to communicate as phone lines may be overloaded
Expect aftershocks and be ready to Drop, Cover, and Hold On again
Turn off gas, water, and electricity if you suspect damage
Listen to local radio or TV for emergency information and instructions
Help neighbors who may need assistance, especially elderly or disabled individuals

title: Flood
overview: Floods are high water levels that submerge land that's usually dry. They can be caused by heavy rainfall, storm surges, or dam failures.
tips: Move to higher ground immediately when flood warnings are issued
Avoid walking or driving through flood waters - just 6 inches can knock you down
Disconnect electrical appliances and turn off main power if flooding is imminent
Move valuable items to higher floors or elevated areas
Keep important documents in waterproof containers
Have an evacuation plan and emergency kit ready
response: Listen to local alerts and updates from weather services and emergency management
Boil or treat water before drinking as flood water may be contaminated
Document damage for insurance and aid purposes with photos and videos
Avoid contact with flood water as it may contain sewage, chemicals, or debris
Return home only when authorities say it's safe to do so
Be aware of potential health hazards like mold and contaminated water

title: Wildfire / Fire
overview: Fires can spread quickly and produce dangerous smoke. Wildfires can be natural or human-caused and can devastate large areas.
tips: Stay low to avoid smoke; cover nose and mouth with a wet cloth
Use stairs, not elevators, as elevators may stop working during fires
Have an evacuation plan and emergency kit ready with essential supplies
Keep flammable materials away from heat sources and open flames
Install and maintain smoke detectors on every level of your home
Create a defensible space around your property by clearing vegetation
response: Evacuate immediately if instructed by authorities; keep doors closed behind you
Call emergency services from a safe location outside the building
Treat minor burns with cool water; seek medical care for serious injuries
Stay away from the area until authorities declare it safe to return
Use a fire extinguisher only if the fire is small and you know how to use it
If trapped, signal for help by waving a bright cloth or using a flashlight

title: Cyclone / Hurricane
overview: Cyclones are powerful rotating storms with strong winds and heavy rain that can cause widespread destruction.
tips: Stay indoors and away from windows during the storm
Secure outdoor furniture and objects that could become projectiles
Have a battery-powered radio and extra batteries for updates
Fill bathtubs and containers with water for drinking and sanitation
Keep important documents in waterproof containers
Know your evacuation route and have a plan for pets
response: Listen to weather updates and follow evacuation orders immediately
Stay in the strongest part of your home, away from windows
Use flashlights instead of candles to avoid fire hazards
Avoid using electrical appliances during the storm
After the storm, avoid downed power lines and flooded areas
Check on neighbors and help those who may need assistance

title: Tsunami
overview: Tsunamis are large ocean waves caused by underwater earthquakes, volcanic eruptions, or landslides.
tips: Move to higher ground immediately if you feel a strong earthquake near the coast
Never go to the beach to watch a tsunami - it's extremely dangerous
Listen to tsunami warnings and evacuation orders from authorities
Have an evacuation plan and know the quickest route to higher ground
Keep emergency supplies in your car and at home
Stay away from the coast until authorities say it's safe to return
response: Evacuate immediately when tsunami warnings are issued - don't wait
Move inland and to higher ground as quickly as possible
If you can't evacuate, go to the upper floors of a sturdy building
Stay away from the coast for several hours after the initial wave
Listen to local radio for updates and safety information
Help others evacuate if you can do so safely
